name: CHALLENGER II
description:
This computer is based on the MODEL 500 CPU board. It is actually a Super Kit (see Model 500) assembled with a cassette interface and a keyboard. OHIO Scientific presented two enhanced versions of the Challenger IIP : the Challenger II Disk Systems and the Challenger III.
The Disk System version came with 16 KB of RAM (expandable to 192 KB)instead of ROM BASIC and one or two 8'' F.D. drives. The disk BASIC was automatically loaded into the RAM. Up to 4 independant users could be connected simultaneously. The basic version with a single F.D. drive costed $1964.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> THE CHALLENGER II DISK SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Each Disk can store 250 KB. Unlike the Challenger IIP, the motherboard isn't in the keyboard case but in the box above the FDD. Two versions of the Challenger Disk System were available : the first one used a monitor and had a video output, the second one used a terminal and had a serial port (RS232 ?). This model doesn't use a specific operating system, but a special version of Basic (16 KB ROM on the disk controller)</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert from Byte magazine (january 1977) said : <br><br>  ...It gets its speed and power from a selected version of the new Z80 microprocessor that can operate at a 4 Mhz. clock rate (The Z-1 also lets you switch to 2 Mhz. to be compatible with older systems)...<br> ...The Z-1 offers you all kinds of peripherals and softwares. It uses the standard ''S100'' bus supported by over a dozen manufacturers. And all Cromemco peripherals (PROM memory and programmer, Ram memory, analog I/O, color TV interface, etc) just plug into the Z1's sockets...<br> ... The Z-1 comes completely assembled ans tested. It's a quality, commercial grade microcomputer. It is not available as a kit.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>She seems so happy to have an Hit-Bit...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #6</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US DEALER ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Until now, parents interested in expanding their children's educational experience, turned to expensive encyclopedias. With the advent of the PET personal computer a new avenue of visual learning is now available for your youngsters for as low as $595....<br><br> ... Your youngster will think he's playing, you'll know he's learning with the remarkable PET... </font><br><br> At the time, parents often thought a personal computer could help their youngsters learning, but 80% of the home computers sold in the 80's was used only for playing. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Douglas Reedy</p></blockquote>
